subject: control: PCIe card metadata wrapper class
commitMessage:
control: PCIe card metadata wrapper class

This class introduces a PCIeCardMetadata class to manage JSON files
containing PCIe card floor indexes. These can then be used by actions
that want to set the fan floors based on which PCIe cards are present.

It provides a lookup() method that takes four properties from the
PCIeDevice D-Bus interface to uniquely identify a card, and then returns
the floor index for the card if it doesn't have a temperature sensor on
it, or the 'has temp sensor' value which will be true.

The code first loads /etc/phosphor-fan-presence/control/pcie_cards.json
if it exists.  If that isn't present, it then tries
/usr/share/phosphor-fan-presence/control/pcie_cards.json.  After
that, it tries
/usr/share/phosphor-fan-presence/control/<system-name>/pcie_cards.json
where <system-name> comes from the list of system names passed into
the constructor.

It will overwrite any file entries that match as it goes on, so if a
system has to override just a few of the floor indexes from a more
generic file it can be done without having to duplicate entries for
cards that are the same.

Signed-off-by: Matt Spinler <spinler@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I81f2476dd58d1529ee6484243e7d8f1e49027cf9

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as e9d33b6533bb5b919e9e63b74b1bfa8f9b1525e5
Removed reviewer Brandon J. Wyman.
How is the ordering of inserting systemNames enforced to accept a list that could be given not based on the IBMCompatible interface?
I would say if someone wants to pass in a list based on something else then they could order it appropriately so this code still works.  Not sure who would do that though?
Ack
But giving a default_floor_index is optional, right?
no.  the default index is used when a PCIe card is in the system but not in the list.
according to lines 169-172 default_floor_index is optionally given
As discussed, I will remove the default floor index completely.
Done
May want to consider listing out the JSON attributes in the exception message saying that one or more are missing, I had done this to make it easier to debug or find typos in the JSON config.
Ack
Isnt this already be caught on line 119?
Ack
Couldnt 0 be a valid index?
Can't remember why I did this, could probably just do std::get<int32>
Done
regular
Done
`sensor_name` is used in the JSON, can this support more than one sensor? If so, the sensor names have to collectively be represented with a regular expression?
Yea, though frankly I think we've since talked ourselves out of needing any of that, so maybe I can just remove it.
I removed the sensor name stuff since I don't think we'll need to use it.
Done
An optional
Done
first? Isnt this just the config file name to load?

As it is now it'll look in baseConfigFile first and then override any entries it also finds in the systemNames files.

The idea is that you could put common stuff in there, and then any deltas under the system specific dirs.  So in this case if baseConfigFile = pcie_cards.json it would look in control/pcie_cards.json.  

I guess I could change that to a bool and if true then default to control/pcie_cards.json.

If it's false, then it would only ever look in the systemNames dirs.  I guess alternatively to that even I could look in control/pcie_cards.json if systemNames is empty.

We could enforce that the common stuff be at a default(base) location(i.e. not needing to be passed in here then that would result in only needing to pass in a list of additional directory locations given in a priority order be passed to this constructor), then given anything in systemNames locations would overwrite any matching entries from the common one found at the default location?
Rewrote this to just look in the default location if systemNames is empty.
Done
I'd prefer we did not require a list of system names to be provided since all the other config files can be loaded without this interface existing using a default location.
The next commit shows how it will pass in an empty systemNames list.  I think having that code having to chose between 2 constructors would just make it more complicated.

I should clarify.  Whether or not we'll use the IBMCompatibleNames stuff will be specified in the JSON data and the action class that owns this class will then either fill in the names list or leave it empty as needed.

Ok, but with this being a utility class it will always depend on how the the action, etc.. is implemented to use this. At a minimum we should remove the references to "IBMCompatible" since I have a feeling that interface will be deprecated in the future so really this should accept an optional priority ordered list of names to look for pcie json files. FWIW, removing the references to that interface name in the json_config class is on my list to do eventually as well.
Done
What's the reason to have this separate than having the default floor index value get returned by just calling `lookup()`?
Because I want the caller to know if a valid entry was found or not.
Done
Like mentioned above, maybe remove the reference to this interface name and default the systemNames list to be empty so its not required to be given.
Done

But having a default_floor_index in the JSON is optional and 0 could be a valid unintended index? If the lookup fails and not default_floor_index was given, shouldnt it just produce an error or return nothing on the lookup?
it'll crash while loading the JSON if the defaultFloorIndex isn't specified because it isn't optional.
ok, that contradicts the parsing code for `default_floor_index`
Done
Looks like it checks the override location first, then attempts to load the json from the default location.
Done
phosphor
Done (i blame autocomplete)
Probably should make this 2022 now
Done
Might as well update this to 2022 now
Done
